title: Does lender have to resubmit a Motion For Relief after conversion from 7 to 13
question: Converted from 7 to 13, granted on March 25, 2010, however, The Motion For Relief From Automatic stay was granted on January 12, under the Chapter 7. The lender is threating to foreclose on 4/26, 2010, while I have a stay under the chapter 13 in place. What BK fed code applies to stop this foreclosure? Need help NOW 4/23/10
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Bankruptcy documents,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate finances,Foreclosure,Short sales,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Filing a lawsuit,State court
answers:
Unlikely that the conversion helped at all. You need to immediately file a Motion to Reinstate the Automatic Stay. And you need to make it an emergency motion.

You should also getting an offer on your house, and submitting TODAY for a short sale. Some lenders will postpone sale with that. Or submitting a loan modification application. Some lenders will postpone sale with that as well.

Stuart Price

The MFRFS is now going to follow the case regardless if you convert or not. Therefore the bank can foreclose without the protection of the stay. I would suggest that you contact the banks attorney; through the BK petition and attempt to do a short sale and sell the property.
That will assist you in that you will AVOID a foreclosure on your credit report. That is important for your future credit and livelihood. If you need assistance with your short sale I would be more than happen to assist you. The deficiency claim could be then included in your BK petition and you could be debt free 100%
My office does a ton on Short Sales and loss mitigation and would be more than happy to assist.

Order for Relief of Stay survives the conversion from C7 to C13 as to that Creditor. The motion was followed by an Order that was signed by the Judge, right?

The stay you have under the C13 Section 362 et al....does not apply to the above order.

You would have to get a State court to grant a TRO at this point...
or fight the UD by joinder of a Quite Title action for irregularity of sale or foreclosure process...
or if you have fraudulent transfers or securitization or perfection of title during BK...
You need a BK litigator or state court foreclosure litigation specialist and $15-$25K at this point.

Normally the order granting the MFRFAS states specifically that the order is binding despite subsequent conversion to another chapter. That's how it is here in California, where the form order says exactly that. If it does not include such language, or the box is not checked, then you are probably OK. Best to consult with a lawyer on this subject.
